sp.l: Tyrant, I scorn thy threats and menaces,
It is but temporal that thou canst inflict.

sp.speaker: Lan.:
sp.l: The worst is death, and better die to live,
Than live in infamy under such a king.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Away with them my lord of Winchester,
These lusty leaders Warwicke and Lancaster,
I charge you roundly off with both their heads, away.

sp.speaker: War.:
sp.l: Farewell vain world.

sp.speaker: Lan.:
sp.l: Sweet Mortimer farewell.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: England, unkind to thy nobility,
Groan for this grief, behold how thou art maimed.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Go take that haughty Mortimer to the tower,
There see him safe bestowed, and for the rest,
Do speedy execution on them all, be gone.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: What Mortimer? can ragged stony wall
Immure thy virtue that aspires to heaven,
No Edward, England's scourge, it may not be,
Mortimers hope surmounts his fortune far.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Sound drums and trumpets, march with me my friends,
Edward this day hath crowned him king a new.

sp.speaker: Spen.:
sp.l: Lewne, the trust that we repose in thee,
Begets the quiet of king Edwards land,
Therefore be gone in haste, and with advice,
Bestow that treasure on the lords of France,
That therewith all enchanted like the guard,
That suffered Jove to pass in showers of gold
To Danae, all aide may be denied
To Isabell the Queen, that now in France
Makes friends, to cross the seas with her young son,
And step into his fathers regiment.

sp.speaker: Levune.:
sp.l: that is it these Barons and the subtle Queen,
Long levied at.

sp.speaker: Bald.:
sp.l: Yea, but Lewne thou seest,
These Barons lay their heads on blocks together,
What they intend, the hangman frustrates clean.

sp.speaker: Lewn.:
sp.l: Have you no doubts my lords, I will claps close,
Among the lords of France with England's gold,
That Isabell shall make her plaints in vain,
And France shall be obdurate with her tears.

sp.speaker: Spen.:
sp.l: Then make for France, amain Lewne away,
Proclaim king Edwards wars and victories.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: fair blows the wind for France, blow gentle gale,
Till Edmund be arrived for England's good,
Nature, yield to my countries cause in this,
A brother, no, a butcher of thy friends,
Proud Edward, dost thou banish me thy presence?
But I will to France, and cheer the wronged Queen,
And certify what Edwards looseness is,
Unnatural king, to slaughter noble men
And cherish flatterers: Mortimer I stay
Thy sweet escape, stand gracious gloomy night to his device.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Holla, who walketh there, is it you my lord?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Mortimer it is I, but hath thy potion wrought so happily?

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: It hath my lord, the warders all a sleep,
I thank them, gave me leave to pass in peace:
But hath your grace got shipping unto France?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Fear it not.

div1.stage: Enter the Queene and her sonne.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Ah boy, our friends do fail us all in France,
The lords are cruel, and the king unkind,
What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Prince.:
sp.l: Madam, return to England,
And please my father well, and then a Fig
For all my uncles friendship here in France,
I warrant you, I will win his highness quickly,
He loves me better than a thousand Spencers.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Ah boy, thou art deceived at least in this,
To think that we can yet be tuned together,
No, no, we war too far, unkind Valoys,
Unhappy Isabell, when France rejects,
Whether, O whether dost thou bend thy steps.

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.:
sp.l: Madam, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Ah good sir Iohn of Henolt,
Never so cheerless, nor so far distressed.

sp.speaker: S.Ioh.:
sp.l: I hear sweet lady of the kings unkindness,
But droop not madam, noble minds contemn
Despair: will your grace with me to Henolt?
And there stay times advantage with your son,
How say you my Lord, will you go with your friends,
And shake off all our fortunes equally.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: So pleaseth the Queen my mother, me it likes,
The king of England, nor the court of France,
Shall have me from my gracious mothers side,
Till I be strong enough to break a staff,
And then have at the proudest Spencers head.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.:
sp.l: Well said my lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: O my sweet heart, how do I moan thy wrongs?
Yet triumph in the hope of thee my joy,
Ah sweet sir Iohn, even to the utmost verge
Of Europe, or the shore of Tanaise,
Will we with thee to Henolt, so we will,
The Marquis is a noble Gentleman,
His grace I dare presume will welcome me,
But who are these?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Madam, long may you live,
Much happier than your friends in England do.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Lord Edmund and lord Mortimer alive,
Welcome to France: the news was here my lord,
That you were dead, or very near your death.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Lady, the last was truest of the twain,
But Mortimer reserved for better hap,
Hath shaken off the thralldom of the tower,
And lives to advance your standard good my lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: How mean you, and the king my father lives?
No my lord Mortimer, not I, I trow.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Not son, why not? I would it were no worse,
But gentle lords, friendless we are in France.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Monsieur le Grand, a noble friend of yours,
Told us at our arrival all the news,
How hard the nobles, how unkind the king
Hath showed himself: but madam, right makes room,
Where weapons want, and though a many friends
Are made away, as Warwick, Lancaster,
And others of our party and faction,
Yet have we friends, assure your grace in England,
Would cast up caps, and clap their hands for joy,
To see us there appointed for our foes.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Would all were well, and Edward well reclaimed,
For England's honour, peace, and quietness.

sp.speaker: Mort.:
sp.l: But by the sword, my lord, it must be deserved.
The king will never forsake his flatterers.

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.:
sp.l: My Lords of England, sith the ungentle king
Of France refuseth to give aide of arms,
To this distressed Queen his sister here,
Go you with her to Henolt, doubt ye not,
We will find comfort, money, men, and friends
Ere long, to bid the English king a base,
How say young Prince, what think you of the match?

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: I think king Edward will out run us all.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Nay son, not so, and you must not discourage
Your friends that are so forward in your aide.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Sir Iohn of Henolt, pardon us I pray,
These comforts that you give our woeful queen,
Bind us in kindness all at your command.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Yea gentle brother, and the God of heaven,
Prosper your happy motion good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: This noble gentleman forward in arms,
Was born I see to be our anchor hold,
Sir Iohn of Henolt, be it thy renown,
That England's Queen, and nobles in distress,
Have been by thee restored and comforted.

sp.speaker: S. Iohn.:
sp.l: Madam along, and you my lord with me,
That England's peers may Henolts welcome see.

div1.stage: Enter the king, Matr. the two Spencers, with others.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Thus after many threats of wrathful war,
Triumpheth England's Edward with his friends,
And triumph Edward with his friends uncontrolled,
My lord of Gloster, do you hear the news?

sp.speaker: Spen. iu.:
sp.l: What news my lord?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Why man, they say there is great execution
Done through the realm, my lord of Arundell
You have the note, have you not?

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: From the lieutenant of the tower my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: I pray let us see it, what have we there?
Read it Spencer.
Why so, they barked a pace a month ago,
Now on my life, they will neither bark nor bite.
Now sirs, the news from France, Gloster I trow,
The lords of France love England's gold so well,
As Isabell gets no aide from thence.
What now remains, have you proclaimed, my lord,
Reward for them can bring in Mortimer?

sp.speaker: Spen. iu.:
sp.l: My lord, we have, and if he be in England,
He will be had ere long I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: If; dost thou say? Spencer, as true as death,
He is in England's ground, our portmasters
Are not so careless of their kings command.
How now, what news with thee, from whence come these?

sp.speaker: Post.:
sp.l: Letters my lord, and tidings forth of France,
To you my lord of Gloster from Lewne.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Read.

sp.p: My duty to your honour promised, I have according to instructions in that behalf, dealt with the king of France his lords, and affected, that the Queen all discontented and discomforted, is gone, whither if you ask, with sir Iohn of Henolt, brother to the Marquess, into Flaunders: with them are gone lord Edmund, and the lord Mortimer, having in their company divers of your nation, and others, and as constant report goeth, they intend to give king Edward battle in England, sooner than he can look for them: this is all the news of import. Your honours in all service, Lewne.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Ah villains, hath that Mortimer escaped?
With him is Edmund gone associate?
And will sir Iohn of Henolt lead the round?
Welcome in Gods name Madam and your son,
England shall welcome you, and all your route,
Gallop apace bright Phoebus through the sky,
And dusky night, in rusty iron car,
Between you both, shorten the time I pray,
That I may see that most desired day,
When we may meet these traitors in the field.
Ah nothing grieves me but my little boy,
Is thus misled to countenance their ills,
Come friends to Bristow, there to make us strong,
And winds as equal be to bring them in,
As you injurious were to bear them forth.

div1.stage: Enter the Queene, her sonne, Edmund, Mortimer, and sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Now lords, our loving friends and countrymen,
Welcome to England all with prosperous winds,
Our kindest friends in Belgia have we left,
To cope with friends at home: a heavy case,
When force to force is knit and sword and glove,
In civil broils makes kin and country men,
Slaughter themselves in others and their sides
With their own weapons gored, but what is the help?
Misgoverned kings are cause of all this wrack,
And Edward thou art one among them all,
Whose looseness hath betrayed thy land to spoil,
And made the channels overflow with blood,
Of thine own people patron shouldest thou be, but thou.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Nay madam, if you be a warier,
Ye must not grow so passionate in speeches:
Lords, sith that we are by sufferance of heaven,
Arrived and armed in this princes right,
Here for our countries cause swear we to him
All homage, fealty and forwardness,
And for the open wrongs and injuries
Edward hath done to us, his Queen and land,
We come in arms to wreck it with the swords:
That England's queen in peace may repossess
Her dignities and honours, and withal
We may remove these flatterers from the king,
That havocs England's wealth and treasury.

sp.speaker: S. Io.:
sp.l: Sound trumpets my lord and forward let us march,
Edward will think we come to flatter him.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: I would he never had been flattered more.

div1.stage: Enter the King, Baldock, and Spencer the sonne, flying about the stage.

sp.speaker: Spe.:
sp.l: Fly, fly, my Lord, the Queen is overstrong.
Her friends do multiply and yours do fail,
Shape we our course to Ireland there to breath.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: What, was I born to fly and run away,
And leave the Mortimers conquerors behind?
give me my horse and let us reinforce our troupes,
And in this bed of honour die with fame.

sp.speaker: Bal.:
sp.l: O no my lord, this princely resolution
Fits not the time, away, we are pursued.

div1.stage: Edmund alone with a sword and target.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: This way he fled, but I am come too late,
Edward, alas my heart relents for thee,
Proud traitor Mortimer why dost thou chase
Thy lawful king thy sovereign with thy sword?
Vild wretch, and why hast thou of all unkind,
Borne arms against thy brother and thy king?
Reign showers of vengeance on my cursed head
Thou God, to whom in justice it belongs,
To punish this unnatural revolt:
Edward, this Mortimer aims at thy life:
O fly him then, but Edmund calm this rage,
Dissemble or thou diest, for Mortimer
And Isabell do kiss while they conspire,
And yet she bears a face of love forsooth:
Fie on that love that hatcheth death and hate.
Edmund away, Bristow to Longshankes blood
Is false, be not found single for suspect:
Proud Mortimer pries near into thy walks.

div1.stage: Enter the Queene, Mortimer, the young Prince and Sir Iohn of Henolt.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Successful battles gives the God of kings,
To them that fight in right and fear his wrath:
Since then successfully we have prevailed,
Thanks be heavens great architect and you,
Ere farther we proceed my noble lords,
We here create our well-beloved son,
Of love and care unto his royal person,
Lord warden of the realm, and sith the fates
Have made his father so infortunate,
Deal you my lords in this, my loving lords,
As to your wisdoms fittest seems in all.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Madam, without offence if I may ask,
How will you deal with Edward in his fall?

sp.speaker: Prince.:
sp.l: Tell me good uncle, what Edward do you mean?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Nephew, your father, I dare not call him king.

sp.speaker: Mor.:
sp.l: My lord of Kent, what needs these questions?
It is not in her controlment, nor in ours,
But as the realm and parliament shall please,
So shall your brother be disposed of,
I like not this relenting mood in Edmund,
Madam, it is good to look to him betimes.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: My lord, the Mayor of Bristow knows our mind.

sp.speaker: Mor.:
sp.l: Yea madam, and they scape not easily,
That fled the field.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Baldock is with the king,
A goodly chancellor, is he not my lord?

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.:
sp.l: So are the Spencers, the father and the son.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: This Edward is the ruin of the realm.

div1.stage: Enter Rice ap Howell, and the Maior of Bristow, with Spencer the father.

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: God save Queen Isabell, and her princely son,
Madam, the Mayor and Citizens of Bristow,
In sign of love and duty to this presence,
Present by me this traitor to the state,
Spencer, the father to that wanton Spencer,
That like the lawless Catiline of Rome,
Reveled in England's wealth and treasury.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: We thank you all.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Your loving care in this,
Deserveth princely favours and rewards,
But where is the king and the other Spencer fled?

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: Spencer the son, created earl of Gloster,
Is with that smooth tongued scholar Baldock gone,
And shipped but late for Ireland with the king.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Some whirl wind fetch them back, or sink them all:
They shall be started thence I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: Shall I not see the king my father yet?

sp.speaker: Edmund.:
sp.l: Unhappy is Edward, chaste from England's bounds.

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.:
sp.l: Madam, what resteth, why stand ye in a muse?

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: I rue my lords ill fortune, but alas,
Care of my country called me to this war.

sp.speaker: Mort.:
sp.l: Madam, have done with care and sad complain,
Your king hath wronged your country and himself,
And we must seek to right it as we may,
Mean while, have hence this rebel to the block,
Your lordship cannot privilege your head.

sp.speaker: Spen. pa.:
sp.l: Rebel is he that fights against his prince,
So fought not they that fought in Edwards right.

sp.speaker: Mort.:
sp.l: Take him away, he prates, you Rice ap howell,
Shall do good service to her Majesty,
Being of countenance in your country here,
To follow these rebellious runagates,
We in mean while madam, must take advise,
How Baldocke, Spencer, and their complices,
May in their fall be followed to their end.

div1.stage: Enter the Abbot, Monkes, Edward, Spencer, and Baldocke.

sp.speaker: Abbot.:
sp.l: Have you no doubt my Lord, have you no fear,
As silent and as careful will we be,
To keep your royal person safe with us,
Free from suspect, and fell invasion
Of such as have your majesty in chase,
Yourself, and those your chosen company,
As danger of this stormy time requires.

sp.speaker: Edwa.:
sp.l: Father, thy face should harbour no deceit,
O hadst thou ever been a king, thy heart
Pierced deeply with sense of my distress,
Could not but take compassion of my state,
Stately and proud, in riches and in train,
Whilom I was powerful and full of pomp,
But what is he, whom rule and empery
Have not in life or death made miserable?
Come Spencer, come Baldocke, come sit down by me,
Make trial now of that philosophy,
That in our famous nurseries of arts
Thou suckedest from Plato, and from Aristotle.
Father, this life contemplative is heaven,
O that I might this life in quiet lead,
But we alas are chaste, and you my friends,
Your lives and my dishonour they pursue
Yet gentle monks, for treasure, gold nor fee,
Do you betray us and our company.

sp.speaker: Monks.:
sp.l: Your grace may sit secure, if none but we do wot of your abode.

sp.speaker: Spen.:
sp.l: Not one alive, but shrewdly I suspect,
A gloomy fellow in a mead below,
He gave a long look after us my lord,
And all the land I know is up in arms,
Arms that pursue our lives with deadly hate.

sp.speaker: Bald.:
sp.l: We were embarked for Ireland, wretched we,
With awkward winds, and sore tempests driven
To fall on shore, and here to pine in fear
Of Mortimer and his confederates.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Mortimer, who talks of Mortimer,
Who wounds me with the name of Mortimer
That bloody man? good father on thy lap
Lay I this head, laden with mickle care,
O might I never open these eyes again,
Never again lift up this drooping head,
O never more lift up this dying heart!

sp.speaker: Spen. son.:
sp.l: Look up my lord. Baldock, this drowsiness
Betides no good, here even we are betrayed.

div1.stage: Enter with Welch hookes, Rice vp Howell, a Mower, and the Earle of Leicester.

sp.speaker: Mower.:
sp.l: Upon my life, those be the men ye see

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: Fellow enough, my lord I pray be short,
A fair commission warrants what we do.

sp.speaker: Lei.:
sp.l: The Queens commission, urged by Mortimer,
What cannot gallant Mortimer with the Queen?
Alas, see where he sits, and hopes unseen,
To escape their hands that seek to reave his life:
Too true it is, quem dies vidit veniens supebum,
But Leister leave to grow so passionate,
Spencer and Baldocke, by no other names,
I arrest you of high treason here,
Stand not on titles, but obey the arrest,
It is in the name of Isabell the queen:
My lord, why droop you thus?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: O day! the last of all my bliss on earth;
Centre of all misfortune. O my stars!
Why do you lower unkindly on a king?
Comes Leister then in Isabellas name,
To take my life, my company from me?
Here man, rip up this panting breast of mine,
And take my heart, in rescue of my friends.

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Spen. iu.:
sp.l: It may be come thee yet,
To let us take our farewell of his grace.

sp.speaker: Abbot.:
sp.l: My heart with pity earns to see this sight,
A king to bear these words and proud commands.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Spencer, a sweet Spencer, thus then must we part.

sp.speaker: Spen. iu.:
sp.l: We must my lord, so will the angry heavens.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Nay so will hell, and cruel Mortimer,
The gentle heavens have not to do in this.

sp.speaker: Bald.:
sp.l: My lord, it is in vain to grieve or storm,
Here humbly of your grace we take our leaves,
Our lots are cast, I fear me so is thine.

sp.speaker: Edwa.:
sp.l: In heaven we may, in earth never shall we meet,
And Leister say, what shall become of us

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: Your majesty must go to Killingworth.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Must! it is somewhat hard, when kings must go.

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: Here is a letter ready for your grace,
That waits your pleasure, and the day grows old.

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: As good be gone, as stay and be beknighted.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: A letter hast thou, lay me in a hearse,
And to the gates of hell convey me hence,
Let Pluto's bells ring out my fatal knell,
And hags howl for my death at Charons shore,
For friends hath Edward none, but these, and these,
And these must die under a tyrants sword.

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: My lord, be going, care not for these,
For we shall see them shorter by the heads.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Well, that shall be, shall be: part we must,
Sweet Spencer, gentle Baldocke, part we must,
Hence fained weeds, unfeigned are my woes,
Father, farewell: Leister, thou stayest for me,
And go I must, life farewell with my friends.

sp.speaker: Spen. iu.:
sp.l: O is he gone! is noble Edward gone,
Parted from hence, never to see us more,
Rent sphere of heaven, and fire forsake thy orb,
Earth melt to air, gone is my sovereign,
Gone, gone alas, never to make return.

sp.speaker: Bald.:
sp.l: Spencer, I see our souls are fleeted hence,
We are deprived the sunshine of our life,
Make for a new life man, throw up thy eyes,
And heart and hand to heavens immortal throne,
Pay natures debt with cheerful countenance,
Reduce we all our lessons unto this,
To die sweet Spencer, therefore live we all,
Spencer, all live to die, and rise to fall.

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: Come, come, keep these preachments till you come to the place appointed
You, and such as you are, have made wise work in England.
Will your Lordships away?

sp.speaker: Mower.:
sp.l: Your worship I trust will remember me?

sp.speaker: Rice.:
sp.l: Remember thee fellow? what else,
Follow me to the town.

div1.stage: Enter the king, Leicester, with a Bishop for the crowne.

sp.speaker: Lei.:
sp.l: Be patient good my lord, cease to lament,
Imagine Killingworth castle were your court,
And that you lay for pleasure here a space,
Not of compulsion or necessity.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Leister, if gentle words might comfort me,
Thy speeches long ago had eased my sorrows,
For king and loving hast thou always been:
The griefs of private men are soon allayed,
But not of kings, the forest deer being struck
runs to an herb that closeth up the wounds,
But when the imperial Lions flesh is gored,
He rends and tears it with his wrathful paw,
Highly scorning, that the lowly earth
Should drink his blood, mounts up into the air,
And so it fares with me, whose dauntless mind
The ambitious Mortimer would seek to curb,
And that unnatural queen false Isabell,
That thus hath pent and mewed me in a prison,
For such outrageous passions cloy my soul,
As with the wings of rancour and disdain,
Full often am I soaring up to heaven,
To plain me to the gods against them both.
But when I call to mind I am a king,
Methinks I should revenge me of the wrongs,
That Mortimer and Isabell have done.
But what are kings, when regiment is gone,
But perfect shadows in a sunshine day?
My nobles rule, I bear the name of king,
I wear the crown, but am controlled by them,
By Mortimer, and my unconstant queen,
Who spots my nuptial bed with infamy,
Whilst I am lodged within this cave of care,
Where sorrow at my elbow still attends,
To company my heart with sad laments,
That bleeds within me for this strange exchange.
But tell me, must I now resign my crown,
To make usurping Mortimer a king?

sp.speaker: Bish.:
sp.l: Your grace mistakes, it is for Englands good,
And princely Edwards right we crave the crown.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: No, it is for Mortimer, not Edwards head,
For he is a lamb, encompassed by wolves,
Which in a moment will abridge his life:
But if proud Mortimer do wear this crown,
Heavens turn it to a blaze of quenchless fire,
Or like the snaky wreath of Tisiphon,
Engirt the temples of his hateful head,
So shall not Englands Vines be perished,
But Edwards name survives, though Edward dies.

sp.speaker: Lei.:
sp.l: My lord, why waste you thus the time away,
They stay your answer, will you yield your crown?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Ah Leister, way, how hardly I can brook
To lose my crown and kingdom, without cause,
To give ambitious Mortimer my right,
That like a mountain overwhelms my bliss.
In which extreme my mind here murthered is:
But what the heavens appoint, I must obey,
Here, take my crown, the life of Edward too,
Two kings in England cannot reign at once:
But stay a while, let me be king till night,
That I may gaze upon this glittering crown,
So shall my eyes receive their last content,
My head, the latest honour dew to it,
And jointly both yield up their wished right.
Continue ever thou celestial sun,
Let never silent night possess this clime,
Stand still you watches of the element,
All times and seasons rest you at a stay,
That Edward may be still fair Englands king:
But days bright beams doth vanish fast away,
And needs I must resign my wished crown,
Inhuman creatures, nursed with Tigers milk,
Why gape you for your sovereigns overthrow?
My diadem I mean, and guiltless life,
See monsters see, I will wear my crown again,
What, fear you not the fury of your king?
But hapless Edward, thou art fondly led,
They pass not for thy frowns as late they did,
But seeks to make a new elected king,
Which fills my mind with strange despairing thoughts,
Which thoughts are martyred with endless torments.
And in this torment, comfort find I none,
But that I feel the crown upon my head,
And therefore let me wear it yet a while.

sp.speaker: Tru.:
sp.l: My Lord, the parliament must have present news,
And therefore say, will you resign or no.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: I will not resign, but whilst I live,
Traitors be gone, and join you with Mortimer,
Elect, conspire, install, do what you will,
Their blood and yours shall seal these treacheries.

sp.speaker: Bish.:
sp.l: This answer we will return, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: Call them again my lord, and speak them fair,
For if they go, the prince shall lose his right.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Call thou them back, I have no power to speak.

sp.speaker: Lei.:
sp.l: My lord, the king is willing to resign.

sp.speaker: Bish.:
sp.l: If he be not, let him choose.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: O would I might, but heavens and earth conspire
To make me miserable: here receive my crown,
Receive it? no, these innocent hands of mine
Shall not be guilty of so foul a crime,
He of you all that most desires my blood,
And will be called the murtherer of a king,
Take it: what are you moved, pity you me?
Then send for unrelenting Mortimer
And Isabel, whose eyes been turned to steel,
Will sooner sparkle fire than shed a tear:
Yet stay, for rather than I will look on them,
Here, here: now sweet God of heaven,
Make me despise this transitory pomp,
And sit for aye enthronized in heaven,
Come death, and with thy fingers close my eyes,
Or if I live, let me forget myself.

sp.speaker: Bartley.:
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Call me not lord,
Away, out of my sight, ah pardon me,
Grief makes me lunatic,
Let not that Mortimer protect my son,
More safety is there in a Tigers jaws,
This his embracements, bear this to the queen,
Wet with my tears, and dried again with sighs,
If with the sight thereof she be not moved,
Return it back and dip it in my blood,
Commend me to my son, and bid him rule
Better than I, yet how have I transgressed,
Unless it be with too much clemency?

sp.speaker: Tru.:
sp.l: And thus, most humbly do we take our leave.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Farewell, I know the next news that they bring,
Will be my death, and welcome shall it be,
To wretched men death is felicity.

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: An other post, what news brings he?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Such news as I expect, come Bartley, come,
And tell thy message to my naked breast.

sp.speaker: Bart.:
sp.l: My lord, think not a thought so villainous
Can harbour in a man of noble birth.
To do your highness service and devour,
And save you from your foes, Bartley would die.

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: My lord, the counsel of the Queen commands,
That I resign my charge.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: And who must keep me now, must you my lord?

sp.speaker: Bart.:
sp.l: Aye, my most gracious lord, so it is decreed.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: By Mortimer, whose name is written here,
Well may I rent his name, that rends my heart,
This poor revenge hath something eased my mind,
So may his limbs be torn, as is this paper,
Hear me immortal Jove, and grant it too.

sp.speaker: Bart.:
sp.l: Your grace must hence with me to Bartley straight.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Whether you will, all places are alike,
And every earth is fit for burial.

sp.speaker: Leist.:
sp.l: Favour him my lord, as much as lieth in you.

sp.speaker: Bart.:
sp.l: Even so betide my soul as I use him.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Mine enemy hath pitied my estate,
And that is the cause that I am now removed.

sp.speaker: Bartley.:
sp.l: And thinks your grace that Bartley will be cruel?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: I know not, but of this am I assured,
That death ends all, and I can die but once,
Leicester, farewell.

sp.speaker: Leicester.:
sp.l: Not yet my lord, I will bear you on your way.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Fair Isabel, now have we our desire,
The proud corrupters of the light-brained king,
Have done their homage to the lofty gallows,
And he himself lies in captivity,
Be ruled by me, and we will rule the realm,
In any case, take heed of childish fear,
For now we hold an old Wolf by the ears,
That if he flip will seize upon us both,
And gripe the sorer being gripped himself,
think therefore madam that imports as much,
To erect your son withal the speed we may,
And that I be protector over him,
For our behoof will bear the greater sway
When as a kings name shall be under writ.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Sweet Mortimer, the life of Isabel,
Be thou persuaded, that I love thee well,
And therefore so the prince my son be safe,
whom I esteem as dear as these mine eyes,
Conclude against his father what thou wilt,
And I myself will willingly subscribe.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: First would I hear news that he were deposed,
And then let me alone to handle him.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Letters, from whence?

sp.speaker: Messen.:
sp.l: From Killing worth my lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: How fares my lord the king?

sp.speaker: Messen.:
sp.l: In health madam, but full of pensiveness.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Alas poor soul, would I could ease his grief,
Thanks gentle Winchester, sirrah, be gone.

sp.speaker: Winchester.:
sp.l: The king hath willingly resigned his crown.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: O happy news, send for the prince my son.

sp.speaker: Bish.:
sp.l: Further, or this letter was sealed, Lord Bartley came,
So that he now is gone from Killingworth,
And we have heard that Edmund laid a plot,
To set his brother free, no more but so,
The lord of Bartley is so pitiful,
As Leicester that had charge of him before.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Then let some other be his guardian.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Let me alone, here is the privy seal,
who is there, call hither Gurney and Matreuis,
To dash the heavy headed Edmunds drift,
Bartley shall be discharged, the king removed,
And none but we shall know where he lieth.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: But Mortimer, as long as he survives
What safety rests for us or for my son?

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: speak, shall he presently be dispatched and die?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: I would he were, so it were not by my means.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: Enough Matreuis, write a letter presently
Unto the Lord of Bartley from ourself,
That he resign the king to thee and Gurney,
And when it is done, we will subscribe our name.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: It shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: As thou intendest to rise by Mortimer,
Who now makes Fortunes wheel turn as he please,
Seek all the means thou canst to make him droop,
And neither give him kind word, nor good look.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: I warrant you my lord.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: And this above the rest, because we hear
That Edmund casts to work his liberty,
Remove him still from place to place by night,
And at the last, he come to Killingworth,
And then from thence to Bartley back again:
And by the way to make him fret the more,
Speak cursedly to him, and in any case
Let no man comfort him, if he chance to weep,
But amplify his grief with bitter words.

sp.speaker: Matre.:
sp.l: Fear not my Lord, we will do as you command.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: So now away, post thither wards amain.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Whither goes this letter, to my lord the king?
Commend me humbly to his Majesty,
And tell him, that I labour all in vain,
To ease his grief, and work his liberty:
And bear him this, as witness of my love.

sp.speaker: Matre.:
sp.l: I will madam.

div1.stage: Enter the yong Prince, and the Earle of Kent talking with him.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Finely dissembled, do so still sweet Queen,
Here comes the young prince, with the Earl of Kent.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Something he whispers in his childish ears.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: If he have such access unto the prince,
Our plots and stratagems will soon be dashed.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Use Edmund friendly, as if all were well.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: How fares my honourable lord of Kent?

sp.speaker: Edmun.:
sp.l: In health sweet Mortimer, how fares your grace.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Well, if my Lord your brother were enlarged.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: I hear of late he hath deposed himself.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: The more my grief.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Edmun.:
sp.l: Ah they do dissemble.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Sweet son come hither, I must talk with thee.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: Thou being his uncle, and the next of blood,
do lool to be protector over the prince.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Not I my lord: who should protect the son,
But she that gave him life, I mean the Queen?

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: Mother, persuade me not to wear the crown,
Let him be king, I am too young to reign.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: But be content, seeing it his highness pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: Let me but see him first, and then I will.

sp.speaker: Edmund.:
sp.l: I do sweet Nephew.

sp.speaker: Quee.:
sp.l: Brother, you know it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Prince.:
sp.l: Why, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: No, God forbid.

sp.speaker: Edmun.:
sp.l: I would these words proceeded from your heart.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Inconstant Edmund, dost thou favour him,
That wast a cause of his imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: The more cause have I now to make amends.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: I tell thee it is not meet, that one so false
Should come about the person of a prince,
My lord, he hath betrayed the king his brother,
And therefore trust him not.

sp.speaker: Prince.:
sp.l: But he repents, and sorrows for it now.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Come son, and go with this gentle Lord and me.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: With you I will, but not with Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Why youngling, suddenest thou so of Mortimer?
Then I will carry thee by force away.

sp.speaker: Prin.:
sp.l: Help uncle Kent, Mortimer will wrong me.

sp.speaker: Quee.:
sp.l: Brother Edmund, strive not, we are his friends,
Isabel is nearer than the earl of Kent.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Sister, Edward is my charge, redeem him.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Edward is my son, and I will keep him.

sp.speaker: Edmu.:
sp.l: Mortimer shall know that he hath wronged me.
Hence will I haste to Killingworth castle,
And rescue aged Edward from his foes,
To be revenged on Mortimer and thee.

div1.stage: Enter Matreuis and Gurney with the king.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: My lord, be not pensive, we are your friends,
Men are ordained to live in misery,
Therefore come, dalliance dangereth our lives.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Friends, whither must unhappy Edward go,
Will hateful Mortimer appoint no rest?
Must I be vexed like the nightly bird,
Whose sight is loathsome to all winged fowls?
When will the fury of his mind assuage?
When will his heart be satisfied with blood?
If mine will serve, unbowel straight this breast,
And give my heart to Isabel and him,
It is the chiefest mark they level at.

sp.speaker: Gurney.:
sp.l: Not so my liege, the Queen hath given this charge,
To keep your grace in safety,
Your passions make your dolours to increase.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: This usage makes my misery increase.
But can my air of life continue long,
When all my senses are annoyed with stench?
Within a dungeon Englands king is kept,
Where I am starved for want of sustenance,
My daily diet, is heart breaking sobs,
That almost rents the closet of my heart,
Thus lives old Edward not relieved by any,
And so must die, though pitied by many.
O water gentle friends to cool my thirst,
And clear my body from foul excrements.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Here is channel water, as our charge is given,
Sit down, for we will be Barbers to your grace.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Traitors away, what will you murther me,
Or choke your sovereign with puddle water?

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: No, but wash your face, and shave away your beard,
Least you be known, and so be rescued.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Why strive you thus, your labour is in vain?

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: The Wren may strive against the Lions strength.
But all in vain, so vainly do I strive,
To seek for mercy at a tyrants hand.
sp.stage: They wash him with puddle water, and shaue his beard away.
sp.l: Immortal powers, that knows the painful cares,
That waits upon my poor distressed soul,
O level all your looks upon these daring men,
That wrongs their liege and sovereign, Englands king,
O Gaueston, it is for thee that I am wronged,
For me, both thou, and both the Spencers died,
And for your sakes, a thousand wrongs I will take,
The Spencers ghosts, where ever they remain,
Wish well to mine, then tush for them I will die.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Twixt theirs and yours, shall be no enmity,
Come, come, away, now put the torches out,
We will enter in by darkness to Killingworth.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: How now, who comes there?

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Guard the king sure, it is the earl of Kent.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: O gentle brother, help to rescue me.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Keep them a sunder, thrust in the king.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Soldiers, let me but talk to him one word.

sp.speaker: Gur.:
sp.l: Lay hands upon the earl for this assault.

sp.speaker: Edmu.:
sp.l: Lay down your weapons, traitors yield the king.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Edmund, yield thou thyself, or thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Edmu.:
sp.l: Base villains, wherefore do you gripe me thus?

sp.speaker: Gurney.:
sp.l: Bind him, and so convey him to the court.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Where is the court but here, here is the king,
And I will visit him, why stay you me?

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: The court is where lord Mortimer remains,
Thither shall your honour go, and so farewell.

div1.stage: Exeunt Matr. and Gurney, with the king. Manent Edmund and the souldiers.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: O miserable is that common-weal, where lords
Keep courts, and kings are locked in prison!

sp.speaker: Sould.:
sp.l: Wherefore stay we? on sirs to the court.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: aye, load me whether you will, even to my death,
Seeing that my brother cannot be released.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: The king must die, or Mortimer goes down,
The commons now begin to pity him,
Yet he that is the cause of Edwards death,
Is sure to pay for it when his son is of age,
And therefore will I do it cunningly,
This letter written by a friend of ours,
Contains his death, yet bids them save his life.
Fear not to kill the king it is good he die.
But read it thus, and that is an other sense:
Kill not the king it is good to fear the worst.
Unpointed as it is, thus shall it go,
That being dead, if it chance to be found,
Matreuis and the rest may bear the blame,
And we be quit that caused it to be done:
Within this room is locked the messenger,
That shall convey it, and perform the rest,
And by a secret token that he bears,
Shall he be murdered when the deed is done.
Lightborn, come forth, art thou as resolute as thou wast?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: What else my lord? and far more resolute.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: And hast thou cast how to accomplish it?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: aye, aye, and none shall know which way he died.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: But at his looks Lightborne thou wilt relent.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Relent, ha, ha, I use much to relent.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Well, do it bravely, and be secret.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: You shall not need to give instructions,
It is not the first time I have killed a man,
I learned in Naples how to poison flowers,
To strangle with a lawn thrust through the throat,
To pierce the windpipe with a needles point,
Or whilst one is a sleep, to take a quill
And blow a little powder in his ears,
Or open his mouth, and pour quick silver down,
But yet I have a braver way than these.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Nay, you shall pardon me, none shall know my tricks.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: I care not how it is, so it be not spied,
Deliver this to Gurney and Matreuis,
At every ten miles end thou hast a horse.
Take this, away, and never see me more.

sp.speaker: Lightborne.:
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: No, unless thou bring me news of Edwards death.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: That will I quickly do, farewell my lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.:
sp.l: The prince I rule, the queen do I command,
And with a lowly conge to the ground,
The proudest lords salute me as I pass,
I seal, I cancel, I do what I will,
Feared am I more than loved, let me be feared,
And when I frown, make all the court look pale,
I view the prince with Aristorchus eyes,
Whose looks were as a breeching to a boy,
They thrust upon me the Protectorship,
And sue to me for that that I desire,
While at the council table, grave enough,
And not unlike a bashful Puritan,
First I complain of imbecility,
Saying it is,
Till being interrupted by my friends,
that as they term it,
And to conclude, I am Protector now,
Now is all sure, the Queen and Mortimer
Shall rule the realm, the king, and none rule us,
Mine enemies will I plague, my friends advance,
And what I list command, who dare control,
And that this be the coronation day,
It pleaseth me, and Isabell the Queen,
The trumpets sound, I must go take my place.

div1.stage: Enter the yong King, Bishop, Champion, Nobles, Queene.

sp.speaker: Bish.:
sp.l: Long live king Edward, by the grace of God
King of England, and lord of Ireland.

sp.speaker: Cham.:
sp.l: If any Christian, Heathen, Turk, or Jew,
Dares but affirm, that Edwards not true king.
And will avouch his saying with the sword,
I am the Champion that will combat him.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: None comes, sound trumpets.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Champion, here is to thee.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, now take him to your charge.

div1.stage: Enter Souldiers with the Earle of Kent prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: What traitor have we there with blades and bills?

sp.speaker: Sould.:
sp.l: Edmund the Earl of Kent.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: What hath he done?

sp.speaker: Sould.:
sp.l: He would have taken the king away perforce,
As we were bringing him to Killingworth.

sp.speaker: Mortimer. iu.:
sp.l: Did you attempt his rescue, Edmund speak?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Mortimer, I did, he is our king,
And thou compelest this prince to wear the crown.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Strike off his head, he shall have marshall law.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Strike off my head, base traitor I defy thee.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: My lord, he is my uncle, and shall live.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: My lord, he is your enemy, and shall die.

sp.speaker: Edmund.:
sp.l: Stay villains.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Sweet mother, if I cannot pardon him,
Entreat my lord Protector for his life.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Son, be content, I dare not speak a word.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Nor I, and yet methinks I should command,
But seeing I cannot, I will entreat for him:
My lord, if you will let my uncle live,
I will requite it when I come to age.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: It is for your highness good, and for the realms,
How often shall I bid you bear him hence?

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Art thou king, must I die at thy command?

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: At our command, once more away with him.

sp.speaker: Edm.:
sp.l: Let me but stay and speak, I will not go,
Either my brother or his son is king,
And none of both, then thirst for Edmunds blood,
And therefore soldiers whither will you hale me?

div1.stage: They hale Edmund away, and carie him to be beheaded.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: What safety may I look for at his hands,
If that my uncle shall be murthered thus?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Fear not sweet boy, I will guard thee from thy foes,
Had Edmund lived, he would have sought thy death,
Come son, we will ride a hunting in the park.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: And shall my uncle Edmund ride with us?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: He is a traitor, think not on him, come.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Gurney, I wonder the king dies not,
Being in a vault up to the knees in water,
To which the channels of the castle run,
From whence a damp continually ariseth,
That were enough to poison any man,
Much more a king brought up so tenderly.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: And so do I, Matreuis: yesternight
I opened but the door to throw him meat,
And I was almost stifled with the savour.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: He hath a body able to endure,
More than we can inflict, and therefore now,
Let us assail his mind another while.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: Send for him out thence, and I will anger him.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: But stay, who is this?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: My lord protector greets you.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: What is here? I know not how to conster it.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Gurney, it was left unpointed for the nonce,
That is his meaning.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Know you this token, I must have the king?

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Aye stay a while, thou shalt have answer straight.
This villain is sent to make away the king.

sp.speaker: Gurney.:
sp.l: I thought as much.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: And when the murder is done,
See how he must be handled for his labour,
let him have the king,
What else, here is the keys, this is the lake,
Do as you are commanded by my lord.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: I know what I must do, get you away,
Yet be not far off, I shall need your help,
See that in the next room I have a fire,
And get me a spit, and let it be red hot.

sp.speaker: Matre.:
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: Need you anything besides?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: What else, a table and a featherbed.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: that is all.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Aye, Aye, so when I call you, bring it in.

sp.speaker: Matre.:
sp.l: Fear not you that.

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: here is a light to go into the dungeon.

sp.speaker: Lightbor.:
sp.l: So now must I about this gear, never was there any
So finely handled as this king shall be,
Foh, here is a place in deed with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Who is there, what light is that, wherefore comes thou?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: To comfort you, and bring you joyful news.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Small comfort finds poor Edward in thy looks,
Villain, I know thou comest to murther me.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: To murther you my most gracious lord,
Far is it from my heart to do you harm,
The Queen sent me, to see how you were used,
For she relents at this your misery.
And what eyes can refrain from shedding tears,
To see a king in this most piteous state?

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Weepest thou already, list a while to me,
And then thy heart, were it as Gurneys is,
Or as Matreuis, hewn from the Caucuses,
Yet will it melt, ere I have done my tale,
This dungeon where they keep me, is the sink,
Wherein the filth of all the castle falls.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: O villains!

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: And there in mire and puddle have I stood,
This ten days space, and least that I should sleep,
One plays continually upon a Drum,
They give me bread and water being a king,
So that for want of sleep and sustenance,
My mind is distempered, and my body is numbed,
And whether I have limbs or no, I know not,
O would my blood dropped out from every vain,
As doth this water from my tattered robes:
Tell Isabel the Queen, I looked not thus,
When for her sake I ran at tilt in France,
And there unhorsed the duke of Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: O speak no more my lord, this breaks my heart.
Lie on this bed, and rest yourself a while,

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: These looks of thine can harbour naught but death.
I see my tragedy written in thy brows,
Yet stay a while, forbear thy bloody hand,
And let me see the stroke before it comes,
That and even then when I shall lose my life,
My mind may be more steadfast on my God.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: What means your highness to mistrust me thus?

sp.speaker: Edwa.:
sp.l: What means thou to dissemble with me thus?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: These hands were never stained with innocent blood,
Nor shall they now be tainted with a kings.

sp.speaker: Edward.:
sp.l: Forgive my thought, for having such a thought,
One jewel have I left, receive thou this,
Still fear I, and I know not what is the cause,
But every joint shakes as I give it thee:
O if thou harbourest murther in thy heart,
Let this gift change thy mind, and save thy soul,
Know that I am a king, O at that name,
I feel a hell of grief, where is my crown?
Gone, gone, and do I remain alive?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: You are over watched my lord, lie down and rest.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: But that grief keeps me waking, I should sleep,
For not these ten days have these eye lids closed,
Now as I speak they fall, and yet with fear
Open again, O wherefore sits thou here?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: If you mistrust me, I will be gone my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: No, no, for if thou meanest to murther me,
Thou wilt return again, and therefore stay.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: He sleeps.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: O let me not die, yet stay, O stay a while.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: How now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: Something still busseth in mine ears,
And tells me, if I sleep I never wake,
This fear is that which makes me tremble thus,
And therefore tell me, wherefore art thou come?

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: To rid thee of thy life, Matreuis come,

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: I am too weak and feeble to resist,
Assist me sweet God, and receive my soul.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Run for the table.

sp.speaker: Edw.:
sp.l: O spare me, or dispatch me in a trice.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: So, lay the table down, and stamp his body.
But not too hard, least that you bruise his body.

sp.speaker: Matreuis.:
sp.l: I fear me that this cry will raise the town,
And therefore let us take horse and away.

sp.speaker: Light.:
sp.l: Tell me sirs, was it not bravely done?

sp.speaker: Gurn.:
sp.l: Excellent well, take this for thy reward,
Come let us cast the body in the more,
And bear the kings to Mortimer our lord, away.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: Is it done, Matreuis, and the murtherer dead?

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Aye my good Lord, I would it were undone.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Matreuis, if thou now growest penitent
I will be thy ghostly father, therefore choose,
Whether thou wilt be secret in this,
Or else die by the hand of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: Gurney my lord is fled, and will I fear,
Betray us both, therefore let me fly.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Fly to the Savages.

sp.speaker: Matr.:
sp.l: I humbly thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: As for myself, I stand as Jove's huge tree,
And others are but shrubs compared to me,
All tremble at my name, and I fear none,
Let us see who dare impeach me for his death?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Ah Mortimer, the king my son hath news,
His father is dead, and we have murdered him.

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: What if he have? the king is yet a child.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: aye, Aye, but he tears his hair, and wrings his hands,
And vows to be revenged upon us both,
Into the council chamber he is gone,
To crave the aide and succour of his peers,
Aye me, see where he comes, and they with him,
Now Mortimer begins our tragedy.

div1.stage: Enter the king, with the lords.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: Fear not my lord, know that you are a king.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Villain.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: How now my lord?

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: think not that I am frighted with thy words,
My father is murdered through thy treachery,
And thou shalt die, and on his mournful hearse,
Thy hateful and accursed head shall lie,
To witness to the world, that by thy means,
His kingly body was too soon interred.

sp.speaker: Qu.:
sp.l: Weep not sweet son.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Forbid not me to weep, he was my father,
And had you loved him half so well as I,
You could not bear his death thus patiently,
But you I fear, conspired with Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: Why speak you not unto my lord the king?

sp.speaker: Mor. iu.:
sp.l: Because I think scorn to be accused,
Who is the man dare say I murdered him?

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Traitor, in me my loving father speaks,
And plainly saith, it was thou that murderedest him.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: But hath your grace no other proof than this?

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Yes, if this be the hand of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mortim. iu.:
sp.l: False Gurney hath betrayed me and himself.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: I feared as much, murther cannot be hid.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: It is my hand, what gather you by this.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: That thither thou didst send a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: What murtherer? bring forth the man I sent.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Ah Mortimer, thou knowest that he is slain,
And so shalt thou be too: why stays he here?
Bring him unto a hurdle, drag him forth,
Hang him I say, and set his quarters up,
But bring his head back presently to me.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: For my sake sweet son pity Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Madam, entreat not, I will rather die,
Than sue for life unto a paltry boy.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Hence with the traitor, with the murderer.

sp.speaker: Mort. iu.:
sp.l: Base fortune, now I see, that in thy wheel
There is a point, to which when men aspire,
They tumble headlong down, that point I touched,
And seeing there was no place to mount up higher,
Why should I grieve at my declining fall,
Farewell fair Queen, weep not for Mortimer,
That scorns the world, and as a traveller,
Goes to discover countries yet unknown.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: What, suffer you the traitor to delay?

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: As thou receivedest thy life from me,
Spill not the blood of gentle Mortimer.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: This argues, that you spilt my fathers blood,
Else would you not entreat for Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: I spill his blood? no.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: aye madam you, for so the rumour runs.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: That rumour is untrue, for loving thee,
Is this report raised on poor Isabel.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: I do not think her so unnatural.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: My lord, I fear me it will prove too true.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Mother, you are suspected for his death,
And therefore we commit you to the Tower,
Till further trial may be made thereof,
If you be guilty, though I be your son,
think not to find me slack or pitiful.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: Nay, to my death, for too long have I lived,
When as my son thinks to abridge my days.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Away with her, her words enforce these tears,
And I shall pity her if she speak again.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Shall I not mourn for my beloved lord?
And with the rest accompany him to his grave.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: Thus madam, it is the kings will you shall hence.

sp.speaker: Quee.:
sp.l: He hath forgotten me, stay, I am his mother.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: That boots not, therefore gentle madam go.

sp.speaker: Queen.:
sp.l: Then come sweet death, and rid me of this grief.

sp.speaker: Lords.:
sp.l: My lord, here is the head of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: King.:
sp.l: Go fetch my fathers hearse, where it shall lie,
And bring my funeral robes: accursed head,
Could I have ruled thee then, as I do now,
Thou hadst not hatched this monstrous treachery?
Here comes the hearse, help me to mourn my lords,
Sweet father here, unto thy murdered ghost,
I offer up this wicked traitors head,
And let these tears distilling from mine eyes,
Be witness of my grief and innocency.
